title: You Are Who You Know: Inferring User Profiles in Online Social Networks

author: Alan Mislove, College of Computer and Information Science, Northwestern University

segmentation: But this is some work that I did during my graduate career with colleagues at the Max Planck Institute for Software Systems.
And so today I will be talking bout inferring user profiles in online social network.

And when I start my talk by bringing up personal data that's shared on sites like Facebook, and given the sort of research interests of the people in this room and the fact that there's a Twitter feed right over there, I'm going to guess that pretty much everybody has a Facebook account in this room.
And on your Facebook account, you've probably uploaded things like profile information, status updates, photos, videos, comments and so forth.
And when you do this, there's a privacy model that each one of these sites allows you to use where you can choose who among your friends or the rest of the network.

To access each one of these things that you upload, but there may be things that you've decided, or just two private for some reason you don't want to let either Facebook know or let any of your friends know.

So you made the conscious decision not to upload certain things to Facebook and what we found to be really interesting is that there's an ongoing privacy debate about like how user privacy should be exposed and so forth on social networks.
But when reasoning about privacy on these sites, the debate really only focuses on this explicit data.
In other words, profile information that's been uploaded.
Status updates, photos, videos and so forth.
And we found that there actually is a lot of what we call implicit data on these sites.
In other words, data that users didn't explicitly provide, but can be figured out anyway.

We can figure it out anyway from the social network, and so we were wondering is what about other attributes?
Is it just limited sexual orientation, or could you find other things?

So the privacy story is a bit more complicated, and there's sort of two interpretations you can take away from this talk.

Users can be lazy.
